overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students learn that they can only represent some geometric sequences as exponential functions. They show algebraically that they can represent the constant ratio between output values of an exponential function with the variable <math><mi>b</mi></math> in <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>. Students identify the <math><mi>a</mi></math>-value of that form as the <math><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept of the graph of the function.

overview_item_data_items: I can recognize exponential functions and identify the constant ratio and y-intercept in different representations.
I can write a geometric sequence as an exponential function in the form <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>.

I can show that for an exponential function in the form <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, the ratio <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math> is constant and equal to <math><mi>b</mi></math>.
I can identify the horizontal asymptote of an exponential function and describe its meaning.

I can write a geometric sequence as an exponential function in the form <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup></math>.
All geometric sequences are functions. Only geometric sequences with a positive constant ratio are exponential functions.

When a geometric sequence represents an exponential function, you can use the Product of Powers Rule and the definition of negative exponents to rewrite the explicit formula for the sequence as an exponential function.

The form of an exponential function with a constant ratio is <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, where <math><mi>b</mi></math> represents the constant ratio and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></math> represents the <math><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept.

For an exponential function in the form <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup></math> the ratio <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math> is constant and equal to <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>h</mi></msup></math>.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students compare various representations of different sequences and identify which graphs represent a specific function family.
Students convert from the explicit formula of a geometric sequence to function notation.
Students write an exponential function to model a situation and calculate the constant ratio from a corresponding table of values.
Students explore the graphs of exponential functions for input values less than 0.

Students consider the variable <math><mi>b</mi></math> of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, the expression <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, and the common ratio of a geometric sequence.
